frameDefinitions: The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
The Support, a phenomenon or fact,  lends support to a claim or proposed course of action, the Proposition, where the Domain_of_relevance may also be expressed.
An Agent, Actor, Entity, or Medium causes a Phenomenon to be perceived by a Perceiver.
In this frame a Speaker asks an Addressee for something, or to carry out some action.
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
frameExamples: The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
The latest poll results <t>show</t> that support of the president is at an all-time low.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
Support is a fact that lends epistemic support to a claim, or that provides a reason for a course of action. Typically it is expressed as an External Argument.
This is a belief, claim, or proposed course of action to which the Support lends validity. Normally it is expressed as a Finite Clause Complement:
The <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally creates a situation in which the <fen>Perceiver</fen> observes or experiences the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is an entity or idea that is perceived by the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.
The <fen>Perceiver</fen> is made to have a perceptual experience by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
An <fen>Actor</fen> is a sentient being who is exhibiting, possibly uninintentionally, some <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
An object that has some association with a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Medium</fen> through which a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is expressed.
When the event occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the perception of the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.
The <fen>Speaker</fen>, as in other communication frames, is generally an External Argument.
In this frame the <fen>Addressee</fen> can either occur as an NP Object (usually with a following complement clause) or as a PP Complement of verbs or nouns.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the content of the request that can be expressed as a quote, in a finite or non-finite clausal Complement, an NP Object or PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>. The <fen>Medium</fen> is frequently expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>.
The interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the request.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
<fex>The fact that you lied to me</fex> shows that I shouldn't trust you.
The fact that you lied to me shows <fex>that I shouldn't trust you</fex>.
<fex>The judge</fex> ordered the plaintiff to return the money.
The child implored <fex>her parents</fex> to let her stay up late.
<fex>'I'd like an extension,'</fex> begged Pat.
The parents of the missing child made an appeal <fex>on television</fex>.
I urged him to concede <fex>yesterday</fex>.
<fex>Evelyn</fex> spoke feelingly about what happened.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Evelyn spoke candidly <fex>about her past</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Independent Minds Terms of Service
